content:
Hi,
Good puzzle.
This deserves tags like "Floodfill" and "2d grid" so it can be more easily found!
If there are no objections, I'd like to add cover art.

I've made a minor edit "covered in snow" -> "white in snow", to fully cut the confusion with any kind of interest for the snow's volume. (and I think it fits better the new "green valley" theming, but that may be just me)

And I'm approving.

I fell like the snow/valleys wording is indeed much better! Here are just a few concerns.

The last sentence "than the deeper point of either of these valleys" does not make sense, I think you mean something like "take/return the deepest point overall".

The "next to each other" definition of components is slightly ambiguous as "each other" might be interpreted as "pairwise".

The bounds are not accurate enough regarding the actual data, in particular "N<200" while it only goes up to 20. I guess it's because you did not foresee the limit on the size of the input. As having large heights is not important, it might be interesting to add one testcase as large as possible with only 1-9 heights.

Great Problem, fun to solve, medium difficulty is accurate.

I agree with below comments that their is a disturbing, although not confusing, idea:
Either you go for the Mountain landscape, then there is no logical reason why  all the lakes should go up to H.
Or every water containing area goes up to H then make it straight forward H = 0.

As it is, it just removes readability for no justified reason.

I upvoted but can't approved in current state.

As other comments stipulates, it looks closely on the "unflood the world" problem. As several functions and objects would work on both problems, I think it is a path worth to investigate. Ending up with a scenario halving the difficulty of the "unflood the world" while still being coherent.

There is no test case for this rule :
"If there are multiple lakes with the same size, than the deeper point of either of these lakes."

A very interesting idea. A couple of comments:

1) This seems to be a rather complex puzzle. I'd expect it to be at least a medium, and personally would benefit from a math primer at the beginning :)

2) "If the lake is touching the border of the map, it is considered ending at the edge." -> I don't understand how this rule can apply. If there is ever a place where there would be a lake at the edge of the map, it has nothing binding it in and is therefore not a lake and the water should run into the ocean, right?

3) Largest lake = surface area, or amount of water?

4) It's rather hard to visualize with the current setup. I would love to see the example and first problem have single digit numbers on like a 5x5 grid, to make it clearer at first glance and easier to debug that initial setup.

I think it can be a bit confusing when you word the water as "flood". Could you perhaps change it to "sea level"?  I personally think this would be more understandable.

(eg)
" representing the height of the flood (including this value, and under)." 
to
" the sea level"

It's a little confusing having a map of heights measured from a zero point somewhere underwater, especially having the output in that format.
In the first example, "the deepest point of the largest lake on the map" is 19 units deep.
Well, that's the catch in it. It's not sealevel, it's somewhere in the mountains :)

Thanks for this :)
I will try to add everything, in the meantime:

1. I don't think it is that complex.
2. If the lake is next to the end of the map we see, it should be 'ending' there. So if there is a lake-part next to the places we don't know, we consider it just that big, not bigger.
3. Surface area.
4. Ok :)
I think it has been corrected

I was thinking about another direction. If I don't use water, but something else, like just saying "Valleys", and above a certain limit there is snow, and you need to find the deepest point of the largest green valley. It makes it easier to understand. What do you think?
Made some changes, I hope it's better.

Well, I still don't get the "than" (??) in the last sentence.

The "next to another" correction does not solve the problem: To define properly a component, you should not say "a valley is + a local criterion", but either "a local criterion => same valley" (two neighboring green places are in the same valley) or "a valley is + a global criterion" (a valley is a set of green places that are connected to each other by paths through green places).

Finally the "N<20" correction is incorrect as N=20 is used.

Agree with Niako. This description is much better, and with that few mistakes revised it could be accepted.

One more thing: the description says 0 < H < 5000 but the examples are all <= 1200. I know this does not really affect anything, as it is just an offset, but it would be nice if we actually have some test cases close to the limit.

I would also suggest to edit the first para "Under, it is a fruitful paradise" into "At that height and below, it is a fruitful paradise" to ensure consistency with the actual specification.
This way?
"*is* either horizontally or vertically *is* next"

Makes sense :)
Fixed.

That is a great idea indeed !
Then either finding the lowest point of the largest valley or the highest peak in the largest snow area depending on the backup story you can come up with.
(lowest point of largest valley, so that to dig a well for your herd..?)
(highest point for largest snow, to install your panoramic restaurant on your ski resort..?)
Rewritten :)

1. Well I'd be interested in seeing your solution then :) It's not a bad amount of complex by any means, but definitely beyond any of the easy puzzles I played on CG.
2.
3
5
2 4 2
4 3 4 
2 4 2

In my understanding, the answer to this test case would be a "1", because there is only 1 lake on the map, between the 4's at the 3 spot in the middle. This is because, while there may be a "2" on the corner, we assume that everything outside of our map is at 0 and back to sea level. If it is not, then my answer would actually be "3" because I assume that everything around the map is a huge wall containing all the water, it went up to 5, so the 4's  are covered and the whole thing is a lake right now.

Basically, clarification on the behaviours of the edges and the water would be helpful here:
I'd feel saying the edges are 0 is the most intuitive, but otherwise saying they can all assume to be H or something -> either way a hard fast numeric rule I feel is lacking.

Additionally, can you clarify the behaviour of the water? Looking at the new case
8 9 9 8 7
8 2 3 2 7
6 4 5 4 8
9 8 4 2 7
7 8 9 6 5

It seems the water got to height 5. But then with my understanding of the water level rising, there would be no lake, because the entire middle is surrounded by heights greater than 5, so the water would never have flowed in to enter.

3. Thanks
4. Thanks

5.(new) -> can you flip N & H? It's weird to get the amount of rows to come, THEN additional data, then the rows. H N h[] would be more straightforward.

1. I changed it ;)
2. Well, it is 5 lakes, and 2 is the deepest spot. Outside of the borders it's not 0, it is "infinite high". This is what I tought about ending the lakes at the edge.
5. Yep, doing it now.

Thanks :)

Can you also explicitly state in the instructions that the water will cover every tile below the height of the flood/sea level, regardless of its surroundings? That changes it a lot and I didn't understand it til just now :). It also makes the puzzle simpler, and I see why you argue that it's not super complex.
Done :)
Hum, wait, did you reject that problem for that reason alone?

I rejected because it's a bad puzzle.

Not because the description is confusing, but because the concept that it attempts to describe is confused. You can see from the longer comment thread that the author does not understand how water flows - specifically, that disconnected lakes should not have the same height. 
That's why he's having so much trouble finding an unambiguous way to say "all lakes have water up to height H". It contradicts our intuition about floods.

So whereas his other puzzles did use a "map of fields and lakes," this one requires us to pick one number out of an array based on an arbitrary criterion. It doesn't fit the theme.

Although the author has returned and made some superficial improvements after his original nonresponsiveness, I don't think the fundamental problem can be salvaged without turning this into the existing "flood the world" puzzle.

Ok, thanks for your answer. I feel like the problem is not bad, but the statement certainly is. The problem literally is "find the smallest value inside the largest 4-connected component of values <=H", while the statement tries to make it look like some quirky flood fill problem.
Removing the "flood part" of it, as well as H, and simply giving a topographic map (with negative values under water) and ask for the deepest point in the largest sea/lake would probably make it OK.
Well you just have to substract H to all the integers from the input

Yeah sure, but people are getting confused by the idea that water has reached level H then receded. Because with such an explanation, why would a potential lake, that is by definition surrounded by borders of height >H, even contain water?
